facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 153 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 153 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated January 9, 1956 of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 2258 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 9, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 2258 of 1955

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on March 27, 1961 by WANCHOO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 27. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-This appeal by special leave against the judgment of the Bombay High Court

facts.text: Appellant is the landlord and respondent is a protected tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these The appellant is the landlord and the respondent a protected tenant.

facts.text: Appellant gave notice of termination of tenancy to respondent on December 31, 1951 under s. 34(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant gave numberice of termination of tenancy to the respondent on December 31, 1951, under s. 34 1  of the Act. The numberice was for one year as required by s. 34 1  and the tenancy was to terminate from after March 31, 1953.

facts.text: Notice was for one year and tenancy to terminate after March 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice was for one year as required by s. 34 1  and the tenancy was to terminate from after March 31, 1953. The landlord therefore made an application on April 7, 1953, under s. 29 2  of the Act for obtaining possession of the land to the Mamlatdar.

facts.text: Landlord made application on April 7, 1953 under s. 29(2) of the Act to Mamlatdar for possession.

anchor.surface_text: The landlord therefore made an application on April 7, 1953, under s. 29 2  of the Act for obtaining possession of the land to the Mamlatdar. In the meantime, an amendment. was made to the Act by the insertion of sub-s.  2-A  to s. 34 by the Amending Act No. XXXIII of 1952,

facts.text: Amending Act No. XXXIII of 1952 inserted sub-s. (2-A) to s. 34, came into force on January 12, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, an amendment. was made to the Act by the insertion of sub-s.  2-A  to s. 34 by the Amending Act No. XXXIII of 1952, which came into force on January 12, 1953.

facts.text: Tenant objected to application and claimed benefit of third clause of sub-s. (2-A).

anchor.surface_text: When therefore the landlord applied for possession of the land under s. 29 2  of the Act, the tenant objected and claimed the benefit of the third clause of subs.  2-A ,

facts.text: Mamlatdar allowed the landlord's application under s. 29(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Mamlatdar to whom the application under s. 29  2  was made allowed the application.

facts.text: Tenant's appeal against Mamlatdar's order was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon appealed but his appeal was dismissed. He then went in revision to the Revenue Tribunal, which was rejected.

facts.text: Tenant's revision to Revenue Tribunal was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: He then went in revision to the Revenue Tribunal, which was rejected. The tenant then filed an application under Art. 227 of the Constitution before the High Court

facts.text: Tenant filed application under Art. 227 before Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The tenant then filed an application under Art. 227 of the Constitution before the High Court and companytended that the provision of s. 34 2-A  should have been taken into companysideration

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed tenant's application under Art. 227.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the application of the tenant, relying on its previous Full-Bench decision in Durlabbhai Fakirbhai v. Jhaverbhai Bhikabhai  1 ,

facts.text: High Court relied on Durlabbhai Fakirbhai v. Jhaverbhai Bhikabhai (1956) 58 Bom. L.R. 85.

anchor.surface_text: relying on its previous Full-Bench decision in Durlabbhai Fakirbhai v. Jhaverbhai Bhikabhai  1 , where it was held that as the tenancy had  1   1956  58 Bom. L.R. 85. terminated

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that sub-s. 2-A applies to cases where tenancy terminated after Amending Act came into force.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we are of opinion that the view taken by the High Court is companyrect and sub-s.  2-A  would apply to all cases where numberices might have been given but where the tenancy had number actually terminated before the companying into force of the Amending Act.

arguments.claim: s.34(2-A) does not apply to notices given before Amending Act as right to terminate arises on date of notice

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellant is that s. 34 1  gives a right to the landlord to terminate the tenancy by one years notice, which was given in this case in December 1951 before the Amending Act came into force. Therefore the notice having been given before the Amending Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rice under s. 34 1  is merely a declaration to the tenant of the intention of the landlord to terminate the tenancy but it is always open to the landl

arguments.court_reasoning: No force; sub-s.(2-A) conditions right to terminate exercised on termination date, not notice date

arguments.claim: Applying s.34(2-A) to pre-Amending Act notices takes away landlord's vested right

anchor.surface_text: Nor are we impressed by the argument that by applying sub-s.  2-A  to notices issued before the Amending Act came into force we would be taking away the vested right of the landlord.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ain possession of the land. Therefore, the Amending Act did number affect any vested right of the landlords till the tenancy actually stood terminated

arguments.court_reasoning: Notice merely declares intention; vested right only accrues on actual termination after notice expiry

arguments.claim: Crucial date for s.34(2-A) is termination of tenancy, not notice, as it conditions exercise of right to terminate

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is no force in this contention. If we look at the words of sub-s.  2-A , it provides, certain conditions subject to which the right to terminate the tenancy shall be exercised... crucial date is not the date of notice but the date on which the right to terminate matures

arguments.claim: Notice under s.34(1) is mere declaration of intention to terminate

anchor.surface_text: A notice under s. 34 1  is merely a declaration to the tenant of the intention of the landlord to terminate the tenancy but it is always open to the landlord not to carry out his intention.

arguments.claim: Vested right to possession arises only after tenancy terminates on notice expiry

anchor.surface_text: As we have already pointed out, the notice under s. 34  1  is merely a declaration... It is only when the period of notice has expired and the tenancy has terminated that the landlord acquires a vested right to obtain possession of the land.

arguments.claim: Amending Act is beneficent legislation for tenants; doubt in s.34(2-A) resolved in tenant's favour

anchor.surface_text: That consideration is that the Amending Act is a piece of beneficent legislation meant for the protection of tenants. Therefore, if there is any doubt about the meaning of sub-s.  2-A  that doubt should be resolved in favour of the tenant,

arguments.claim: Amendment does not apply to notices given before, analogous to Jeebankrishna precedent

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has drawn our attention in this connection to Jeebankrishna Chakrabarti v. Abdul Kader Chaudhuri  1 . In that case, the Bengal Tenancy Act was amended... the Calcutta High Court held that it did not.

arguments.court_reasoning: Circumstances different; there notice period changed, here same period but new conditions on termination; no provision invalidating prior notices

arguments.claim: Jeebankrishna precedent distinguishable as circumstances different from present case

holdings.text: The view taken by the High Court is correct and sub-s. (2-A) would apply to all cases where notices might have been given but where the tenancy had not actually terminated before the coming into force of the Amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we are of opinion that the view taken by the High Court is correct and sub-s.  2-A  would apply to all cases where numberices might have been given but where the tenancy had number actually terminated before the companying into force of the Amending Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language imposes restrictions on right to terminate exercised at termination date; notice is mere intention; no vested right before termination; beneficent legislation favors tenants.

holdings.text: For the application of the restriction under sub-s. (2-A) on the right of the landlord to terminate the tenancy, the crucial date is not the date of notice but the date on which the right to terminate matures, that is, the date on which the tenancy stands terminated.

anchor.surface_text: A notice under s. 34 1  is merely a declaration to the tenant of the intention of the landlord to terminate the tenancy but it is always open to the landlord number to carry out his intention. Therefore, for the application of the restriction under sub-s.  2-A  on the right of the landlord to terminate the tenancy, the crucial date is number the date of numberice but the date on which the right to terminate matures, that, is, the date on which the tenancy stands terminated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-s.(2-A) conditions the exercise of termination right, which matures on expiry of notice period; s.34(1) notice declares intention only.

holdings.text: By applying sub-s. (2-A) to notices issued before the Amending Act came into force, no vested right of the landlord is taken away, as vested right to possession arises only when tenancy terminates after notice expiry.

anchor.surface_text: Nor are we impressed by the argument that by applying sub-s.  2-A  to numberices issued before the Amending Act came into force we would be taking away the vested right of the landlord. As we have already pointed out, the numberice under s. 34  1  is merely a declaration... It is only when the period of numberice has expired and the tenancy has terminated that the landlord acquires a vested right to obtain possession of the land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice does not confer vested right; right perfects only on termination; Amending Act applies before vesting.

holdings.text: The tenant was entitled to the protection contained in the third clause of sub-s. (2-A).

anchor.surface_text: When therefore the landlord applied for possession of the land under s. 29 2  of the Act, the tenant objected and claimed the benefit of the third clause of subs.  2-A , and the question that arose for determination was whether the tenant was entitled to the protection contained in this clause

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenancy terminated after Amending Act; landlord must satisfy s.34(2-A) conditions at termination date.

holdings.text: The Amending Act is beneficent legislation for protection of tenants; any doubt about meaning of sub-s. (2-A) resolved in favour of the tenant.

anchor.surface_text: That consideration is that the Amending Act is a piece of beneficent legislation meant for the protection of tenants. Therefore, if there is any doubt about the meaning of sub-s.  2-A  that doubt should be resolved in favour of the tenant, for whose benefit the Amending Act was passed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation favors beneficiaries of tenant protection laws.

holdings.text: Jeebankrishna Chakrabarti v. Abdul Kader Chaudhuri is distinguishable as circumstances different: there notice contents changed and no invalidation of prior notices; here period same, new conditions on termination, crucial date is termination.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent analogy rejected due to factual and legal differences in amendment effects.

anchor.surface_text: Durlabbhai Fakirbhai v. Jhaverbhai Bhikabhai  1

precedents.cited_proposition: Amending Act applies where tenancy terminated after its commencement even if notice given prior thereto; imposes new limitations on landlord's right to possession enforceable at time tenancy expires
precedents.cited_holding: as the tenancy had terminated and the right to obtain possession had accrued to the landlord after the coming into force of the Amending Act, the Amending Act applied and therefore the landlord, if he fails to satisfy the further conditions under the Amending Act, would not be entitled to possession

precedents.citation: Jeebankrishna Chakrabarti v. Abdul Kader Chaudhuri 1

anchor.surface_text: Jeebankrishna Chakrabarti v. Abdul Kader Chaudhuri  1

precedents.case_name: Jeebankrishna Chakrabarti v. Abdul Kader Chaudhuri
precedents.cited_proposition: Amendment requiring fixed one-year notice period for ejectment does not apply to notices already given validly under prior law which allowed shorter or variable notice
precedents.cited_holding: the amendment did not affect notices already given

anchor.surface_text: A notice under s. 34 1  is merely a declaration to the tenant of the intention of the landlord to terminate the tenancy but it is always open to the landlord number to carry out his intention. Therefore, for the application of the restriction under sub-s.  2-A  on the right of the landlord to terminate the tenancy, the crucial date is number the date of numberice but the date on which the right to terminate matures, that, is, the date on which the tenancy stands terminated.

In the circumstances, we are of opinion that the view taken by the High Court is companyrect and sub-s.  2-A  would apply to all cases where numberices might have been given but where the tenancy had number actually terminated before the companying into force of the Amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: Nor are we impressed by the argument that by applying sub-s.  2-A  to numberices issued before the Amending Act came into force we would be taking away the vested right of the landlord. As we have already pointed out, the numberice under s. 34  1  is merely a declaration... It is only when the period of numberice has expired and the tenancy has terminated that the landlord acquires a vested right to obtain possession of the land.

In the circumstances, we are of opinion that the view taken by the High Court is companyrect and sub-s.  2-A  would apply to all cases where numberices might have been given but where the tenancy had number actually terminated before the companying into force of the Amending Act.
